awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Integrated experimental and computational investigations of exogenous surfactant distribution in conducting zone lung airways
awd_abstract_narration:
Our lungs contain a branching network of airways. Lung stability and normal breathing is maintained by a natural substance called surfactant. The lungs of most premature babies are underdeveloped and lack surfactant, making breathing very difficult for the newborn. These babies often receive a treatment that involves instilling a surfactant solution into their windpipe. Airflow from a ventilator is then used to direct the solution into the lung airways. The success of this treatment heavily depends on the uniformity of distribution of surfactant in airways. However, evidence from x-ray imaging shows non-uniform surfactant distribution, leading to a poor response to the treatment. Improving this treatment and its effectiveness has proved difficult due to inaccessibility of airways. This project will address this unresolved issue by using a combined experimental and simulation approach. We will design realistic models of human lung airways, use them to study surfactant delivery to the lungs, and determine delivery conditions that lead to a uniform surfactant distribution, thereby making the treatment more effective. In addition to providing training opportunities to students and promoting diversity through outreach programs, our project will also make a transformative impact through developing new tools and elucidating fluid flow in lung airways. 

The overarching goal of this project is to understand fluid dynamics of surfactant delivery and distribution in conducting zone airways. Using a set of design rules, we generate 3D computational models of airway tree and fabricate them using additive manufacturing. We will then use complementary experimental and computational studies to quantitatively elucidate how fluid type (Newtonian and non-Newtonian surfactants), airflow type (constant vs cyclic), and gravitational orientation of the airway tree affect surfactant deposition and distribution in airways. We will achieve this goal through two specific aims: (i) Quantitatively study surfactant distribution in lung airway tree under constant airflow; and (ii) Cyclic airflow and pre-existing surfactant film effects on surfactant distribution. This work will make a transformative impact on fundamental understanding of fluid dynamics of multi-phase flow in lung airways and lead to design of strategies to enhance surfactant replacement therapy.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
Surfactant replacement therapy (SRT) is a medical procedure to treat prematurely born infants  who develop respiratory distress syndrome due to deficiency of pulmonary surfactant in the lung airways. The pulmonary surfactant helps to keep the airways open, allowing normal breathing. The SRT procedure is performed by instilling a liquid bolus of surfactant into the airway and using the airflow to push the liquid plug into the lung airway. The surfactant plug then propagates along the lung airways, depositing its mass and providing the missing surfactant. However, SRT has a relatively high non-response rate, primarily due to the challenges of delivering the surfactant uniformly, and reaching the distal regions of the lung. 

This project investigated the fluid dynamics of plug flow in straight and bifurcating capillary tubes, modeling the lung airways, by using computational simulations and theoretical approaches. Among the crucial aspects of physics is the viscous behavior of surfactants employed in SRT. These surfactants exhibit non-Newtonian viscosity, unlike the Newtonian viscosity observed in pure water. Furthermore, there is strong interaction between the non-Newtonian plug, a Newtonian pre-existing film coating conducting zone of the lung and the surrounding air, forming a three-fluid system.  A novel computational method to accurately capture and model the viscous effects and interaction in such complex three-fluid flow of non-Newtonian and Newtonian fluids was developed. To ensure its accuracy, the computational method was assessed using a series of systematic tests and ultimately validated. Equipped with the above method, our computational simulation tool was then used to develop a dataset of controlled computational experiments of plug flow under various conditions, where the impact of important parameters on plug film deposition and plug splitting was carefully assessed and analyzed. To make the findings of the project more accessible and helpful to SRT and other relevant applications, theoretical models that predict the plug dynamics and splitting were developed. The theoretical models were informed by our computational dataset and were also tested and validated using data published by other researchers. This project introduced new computational methods and results as well as theoretical models, forming a broad knowledge base that can help and support future research in SRT and other industrial, clinical and research applications involving non-Newtonian plug flow. 

The project also provided scientific and technical training to a PhD student and an undergraduate student, resulting in a highly skilled workforce in computational fluid dynamics and scientific computing.

 


Last Modified: 03/16/2025
Modified by: Mehdi Raessi
